awd_titl_txt: Equipment: University of Hawaii R/V Kilo Moana Oceanographic Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
Kilo Moana is a 186-foot, general-purpose research vessel built in 2002 and operated by the University of Hawaii under a charter party agreement with the Office of Naval Research (ONR). The vessel is part of the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF) and is supported by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Ship time is made available to academic researchers funded by the NSF, ONR, NOAA, NASA, and other federal and state agencies. 

The University of Hawaii requests funds for purchase of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

Reverse Osmosis/ Ultrapure Scientific Water System	$23,576	
OTDR/Copper Network Tester	$19,746	
Overboard Handling System (OHS) Proof Load Test Kit	$18,557	
Hydrostatic Wire Cutter (2)	$6,000	(not funded)
Funded total $61,879	
			
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition,  maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
ABSTRACT

 Kilo Moana is a 186-foot, general-purpose research vessel built in 2002 and operated by the University of Hawaii under a charter party agreement with the Office of Naval Research (ONR). The vessel is part of the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF) and is supported by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Ship time is made available to academic researchers funded by the NSF, ONR, NOAA, NASA, and other federal and state agencies.

The University of Hawaii requests funds for purchase of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

1) Reverse Osmosis/Ultrapure Scientific Water System:  $23,576
2) OTDR & Copper Network Tester:  $19,746
3) Overboard Handling System (OHS) Proof Load Test Kit:  $18,557
Total $ 61,879

Broader Impacts

The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

 The University of Hawaii (UH) supports a research vessel that provides a platform for innovative research in the fields of oceanography, marine biology, geology and atmospheric science.  The ability to accurately assess subsurface currents is fundamental to the interpretation of properties that characterize water masses analyzed by sensor suites such as CTD systems.  The funds provided were used to enhance the vessel’s capability to support a broad range of scientific research.  These included the ability to produce ultrapure scientific water needed to support oceanographic chemistry experiments, diagnostic tools to maintain the vessel’s scientific network and equipment needed to load test the vessel’s overboard handling systems and thus to ensure safe operation of those systems.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: James S Ferguson
